runs.text: Explain that a compound word is made up of two or more smaller words. Often, we can use the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the longer word.

Have students listen to the sounds on the Articulation Video. Then display the Sound-Spelling Card silent letters. Explain that the wr spelling stands for the /r/ sound in write. The kn and gn spellings stand for the /n/ sound in knee and gnat. Each of these spellings has a silent lettera letter we dont pronounce when sounding out the word.
Model identifying the two smaller words in the compound word
. Read each smaller word then blend them together to read the compound word. Model using the meanings of the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the compound word.
Model identifying the silent letter spelling in
Guide students to make compound words using the following smaller words:
Then have them identify the silent letter in each word.
(Add words with skills your students need to review.)
Use the first two words in the first line.
What do you hear thats different in these two words? What do you see thats different?

Then have students chorally read the remaining words in each line. For the first time through the blending lines, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed spelling, stating the sound or sounds, having student repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Read Aloud: All Aboard the Bullet Train!
Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Review that a compound word is made up of two or more smaller words. Often, we can use the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the longer word.

Display the Sound-Spelling Card silent letters. Review that the wr spelling stands for the /r/ sound in write. The kn and gn spellings stand for the /n/ sound in knee and gnat. Each of these spellings has a silent lettera letter we dont pronounce when sounding out the word.
Model identifying the two smaller words in the compound word
. Read each smaller word, then blend them together to read the compound word. Model using the meanings of the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the compound word.
Model identifying the silent letter spelling in
Use the modified Lesson 1 blending words (with additional review words) to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
Corrective Feedback: Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Write the high-frequency words one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Discuss known and unknown word parts.
What syllables do you hear in
? (chil-dren) Look at the beginning of the word. It contains the smaller word
. That helps us remember how to spell it because the words are connected: one child, many children.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Review that a compound word is made up of two or more smaller words. Often, we can use the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the longer word.

Display the Sound-Spelling Card silent letters. Review that the wr spelling stands for the /r/ sound in write. The kn and gn spellings stand for the /n/ sound in knee and gnat. Each of these spellings has a silent lettera letter we dont pronounce when sounding out the word.
Model identifying the two smaller words in the compound word
. Read each smaller word, then blend them together to read the compound word. Model using the meanings of the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the compound word.
Model identifying the silent letter spelling in
Use the Lesson 2 blending words to apply the skill.
Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud.
When completed, guide students to find and circle all the words with
. Then have them put a box around all the compound words.
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words.

Repeat, but dont tell students which letter to change. For example, say:
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words.
Review that a compound word is made up of two or more smaller words. Often, we can use the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the longer word.

Display the Sound-Spelling Card silent letters. Review that the wr spelling stands for the /r/ sound in write. The kn and gn spellings stand for the /n/ sound in knee and gnat. Each of these spellings has a silent lettera letter we dont pronounce when sounding out the word.
Use the new blending lines. Focus attention on modeling for students how to transition from known one-syllable words to multisyllabic words.
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write a sentence for each word on paper or a dry-erase board.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Dictate the following words for students to spell:
. Write the words on the board for students to self-correct. Note on each students
Student Observation Form sound-spellings they struggle with. Include more words with these sound-spellings in upcoming lessons.
Remind students that a compound word is made up of two smaller words. Then read the word
and have students repeat. Circle the two smaller words  (tooth, brush) and remind students that the two smaller words may help them figure out the meaning of the compound word. For example:
A toothbrush is a brush for your teeth.
. Circle the two smaller words in each word and model how to read words syllable by syllable. Have students repeat. Then model how to use the smaller words to define each compound word.
Continue by having students identify the smaller words and read aloud each of the following compound words:
. Guide students to use the smaller words in each compound word to figure out the meaning of the compound word.
Display each word, and guide students to read it.
Model how to sort the words
Have student partners sort the remaining words at their seats.
When completed, have students tell you how to sort the words in the pocket chart. Then have students chorally read the words in each column of the sort.
Ask students what they notice about the words.
If necessary, point out which words contain silent letters.
Encourage students to look for compound words
while reading. Highlight these words as you encounter them.

Display the photos on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Review that a compound word is made up of two or more smaller words. Often, we can use the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the longer word.

Display the Sound-Spelling Card silent letters. Review that the wr spelling stands for the /r/ sound in write. The kn and gn spellings stand for the /n/ sound in knee and gnat. Each of these spellings has a silent lettera letter we dont pronounce when sounding out the word.
Model identifying the two smaller words in the compound word
. Read each smaller word, then blend them together to read the compound word. Model using the meanings of the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the compound word.

Use the new blending words to apply the skill. For the first time through, point to each letter or spelling as students say the sound. Then run your finger under the letters as students blend the sounds orally. Finally, have students say the word.

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you. Guide students to orally segment the word. Then discuss key features of each word to focus students attention on known (regular) and unknown (irregular) word parts.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Finally, have students use each word in an oral sentence.
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequences of words.
Review that a compound word is made up of two or more smaller words. Often, we can use the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the longer word.

Display the Sound-Spelling Card silent letters. Review that the wr spelling stands for the /r/ sound in write. The kn and gn spellings stand for the /n/ sound in knee and gnat. Each of these spellings has a silent lettera letter we dont pronounce when sounding out the word.

Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. Pause before each word for students to whisper-blend it before having them read it together aloud. Provide corrective feedback by pointing to the missed sound-spelling, stating it, having students repeat, then re-blending the word together.
Display the High-Frequency Word Cards one at a time. Point to and say the word, having students repeat after you.
Spell the word as you point to each letter. Then have students chorally spell it with you.
Then have students chorally read the word.
Have students write the word as they spell it aloud.
Read, Build, Write: air, along, begin, children, important, letter, open, own, sound, talk

Display the High-Frequency Word Cards. Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud. Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Extend the learning with one or more of the following activities:
Provide a sentence starter or frame for each word. Have students write and complete the sentences. Then have them read their sentences to a partner (e.g., It is time to begin_____.).
Make a word using Letter Cards. Have students read and spell aloud the word. Then mix the Letter Cards. Have students fix the spelling.
Review that a compound word is made up of two or more smaller words. Often, we can use the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the longer word.

Display the Sound-Spelling Card silent letters. Review that the wr spelling stands for the /r/ sound in write. The kn and gn spellings stand for the /n/ sound in knee and gnat. Each of these spellings has a silent lettera letter we dont pronounce when sounding out the word.
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to apply the skill. When completed, guide students to find and circle all the words with silent letter spellings
. Then have them put a box around each
Use Letter Cards to build the following sequence of words.
knew, know, knot, knit (discuss word meanings and homophones)
wrote, write, writing, writer, songwriter (transition to multisyllabic)

Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
Review that a compound word is made up of two or more smaller words. Often, we can use the smaller words to figure out the meaning of the longer word.

Display the Sound-Spelling Card silent letters. Review that the wr spelling stands for the /r/ sound in write. The kn and gn spellings stand for the /n/ sound in knee and gnat. Each of these spellings has a silent lettera letter we dont pronounce when sounding out the word.
Use the Lesson 6 blending words to quickly review the skill.
When completed, have students select two words.
Ask them to write a sentence for each word on paper or a dry-erase board.
Revisit the sentences to model sentence expanding by adding details. Have students expand one of their sentences.
Read Aloud: Breaking Barriers in Baseball
Display the photo on the opposite side of the Read-Aloud Card as you read.
Use the prompts to highlight the words
Ask students to share their wonderings and questions about the text.
. Remind students that they can use what they know about syllables and spelling patterns to chunk longer words in order to read them.
Model identifying the closed syllables in
. Draw a line to divide the syllable,
. Have students blend the syllables and read the word. Repeat with
(mit/ten). Guide students to divide each word into syllables, read the syllables, then blend the syllables to read the words.
This word means to use a pen to make a mark.
Change the middle letter in write to form the word that means having written in the past.
Replace two letters in the beginning of wrote with one letter to form a word that means a short message.
Add one letter and delete another in note to form a word that names a loop with a rope or string.
Change one letter in knot to form a word that names what you can do with yarn.
Change two letters in the beginning of knit to form a word that names a tiny flying bug.
Read, Build, Write: air, along, begin, children, important, letter, open, own, sound, talk
Call out one word. Have students find the matching word card, repeat the word, and spell it aloud.
Then have students build each word with Letter Cards. Mix the Letter Cards, and have students rebuild it as they point to and say the letters.
